chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of tension-type headache
chapter.summary: Covers the management of adults with episodic or chronic tension-type headache.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage tension-type headache?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the person has any red flags for a serious secondary cause of headache:
    • Refer to secondary care (with urgency depending on the clinical situation).
    • For information on red flags see the section on warning features of serious causes of headache in the CKS topic Headache - assessment.
  • If clinical features are consistent with episodic tension-type (TTH) headache:
    • Offer simple analgesia such as paracetamol, aspirin or a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory taking into account comorbidities and risk of adverse effects — advise the person to take a therapeutic dose as soon as possible after onset of attack.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
    • Do not offer opioids — if needed, reconsider the diagnosis.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Headache - assessment.
    • Identify co-morbidities that may be associated with TTH such as stress, mood disorders, chronic pain and sleep disorders and manage appropriately.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Depression, Generalized anxiety disorder, Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome, Osteoarthritis and Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • If clinical features are consistent with chronic TTH consider preventative treatment with:
    • A course of up to 10 sessions of acupuncture over 5–8 weeks.
      • Acupuncture may not be easily accessible in primary care.
    • Pharmacological prophylaxis with low dose amitriptyline (10-75mg daily) taking into account comorbidities and risk of adverse effects (this is an 'off-label' indication).
      • For people who do not respond — discontinue treatment and discuss with neurology.
      • For people who do respond — attempt withdrawal of medication if improvement is maintained for 4–6 months.
      • For further information, see the Prescribing Section in the CKS topic on Migraine.
  • Provide written and oral patient information on TTH:
    • Patient information on tension headaches is available on the NHS website.
    • Advise the person on the risk of medication overuse headache.
      • People with frequent or chronic TTH may overuse medications to treat attacks and develop medication overuse headache.
      • For further information, see the CKS topic on Headache - medication overuse.
  • If co-existence of TTH and migraine without aura or medication overuse headache is suspected:
    • Advise the person to keep a headache diary recording frequency, severity, characteristics, and duration of attacks along with effectiveness of medications used to help differentiate between headache types.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Headache - assessment, Headache - medication overuse and Migraine.
  • If uncertain about diagnosis/management or first line measures in primary care fail — discuss with a neurologist or GP with a special interest in headache.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of tension-type headache (TTH) are based on the clinical guidelines Guidelines for all healthcare professionals in the diagnosis and management of migraine, tension-type, cluster and medication-overuse headache [BASH, 2010], Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management (updated November 2015) [NICE, 2012], The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (beta version) [IHS, 2013], Diagnosis and treatment of headache [ICSI, 2013] and Guideline for primary care management of headache in adults [Becker, 2015] and expert opinion in review articles [Beran, 2014; Hale, 2014; Yancey, 2014; Dowson, 2015; Green, 2016].

Acute treatment
  • Several clinical guidelines including those from The British Association for the Study of Headache (BASH) [BASH, 2010], The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) [NICE, 2012],  the Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) [ICSI, 2013] and the Institute of Health Economics (Alberta, Canada) [Becker, 2015]  recommend simple analgesia such as aspirin, paracetamol or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories for the acute treatment of tension-type headache (TTH). The person's preference, comorbidities and risk of adverse events should be taken into account.
    • A Cochrane review of 23 studies (n = 8079) found that paracetamol 1000 mg provided a small benefit in terms of being pain free at two hours for people with frequent episodic TTH of moderate or severe intensity. NNT for the outcome pain-free at two hours for paracetamol 1000 mg compared with placebo was 22 (95% CI 15–40) [Stephens, 2016]. 
    • A Cochrane review of 12 studies (n=3094) concluded that ibuprofen 400 mg may relieve headache pain in people with frequent episodic tension-type headache who have an acute headache with moderate or severe initial pain, but the chance of the pain being entirely relieved by 2 hours was low [Derry, 2015].
  • Guidelines from BASH and NICE recommend avoidance of opioids in the acute treatment of TTH [BASH, 2010; NICE, 2012].
    • Evidence on the effectiveness of opioids in the acute treatment of TTH is lacking and the recognised side effects of opioids including an increased risk of medication overuse headache are considerable [NICE, 2012].
Preventative treatment for chronic TTH
  • Acupuncture
    • NICE recommend a course of up to 10 sessions of acupuncture over 5–8 weeks. There is some evidence from single-blind studies that acupuncture reduces the number of headache days compared with sham acupuncture. Although evidence was of low quality, the NICE Guideline Development Group agreed that, because they found very little evidence to support the use of pharmacological prophylaxis, this evidence was sufficient to recommend its use [NICE, 2012].
    • A Cochrane review including 12 trials (n=2,349) concluded that acupuncture may be considered for treating frequent episodic or chronic tension-type headaches [Linde, 2016]. 
      • Acupuncture was compared with routine care of acute headaches in two large trials (1265 and 207 participants). The proportion with at least 50% reduction in headache frequency was higher in groups receiving acupuncture than in control groups (trial 1: 48% versus 19% [RR 2.5: 95% CI 2.1–3.0]; trial 2: 45% versus 4% [RR 11: 95% CI 3.7–35]).
      • Acupuncture was compared with sham acupuncture in seven trials; five large studies provided data for one or more meta-analyses. Among participants receiving acupuncture, 51% had at least 50% reduction of headache frequency compared to 43% in the sham group after treatment (RR 1.3 [95% CI 1.09–1.5]).
    • CKS recognizes that in many areas there may be restrictions on commissioning acupuncture services [DTB, 2010]. It should also be noted that the evidence reviewed by NICE was for the traditional Chinese medicine approach to acupuncture [NICE, 2012], whereas many GPs, nurses, and physiotherapists in the NHS use medical acupuncture rather than the traditional Chinese medicine approach [DTB, 2010].
    • The British Association for the Study of Headache (BASH) state in their guideline on headache that the role of acupuncture is unproven but it may be worth trying in the absence of other options [BASH, 2010].
  • Amitriptyline
    • The NICE guideline on headache [NICE, 2012] does not recommend amitriptyline for prevention of chronic tension-type headache due to a lack of evidence.
    • Several other guidelines such as those from BASH [BASH, 2010], the Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement [ICSI, 2013], and the Institute of Health Economics (Alberta, Canada) [Becker, 2015] recommend amitriptyline for chronic TTH. However, guidance states that evidence does not establish how best to use this drug, or in what dose [BASH, 2010].
    • Expert opinion in several review articles is that evidence for low dose tricyclic antidepressants in reduction of frequency and intensity of attacks in people with chronic TTH is variable [Hale, 2014; Green, 2016; Ghadiri-Sani, 2016; Lozano Lopez, 2016].
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis including 22 randomized controlled trials found that tricyclic antidepressants are modestly effective in reducing chronic tension-type headache frequency compared to placebo (weighted mean differences: -4.8 headaches/month, 95% CI: -6.63 to -2.95) [Jackson, 2017].
Patient information and education
  • Expert opinion in clinical guidelines [NICE, 2012; ICSI, 2013] and review articles [Yancey, 2014; Dowson, 2015; Probyn, 2017] is that patient education on TTH and effective self-management is essential.
  • The guideline from ICHD highlights the importance of distinguishing between frequent episodic tension-type headache and migraine without aura which often co-exist. Patient education allows the person to more accurately identify headache type, select the appropriate treatment and reduce the risk of medication-overuse headache [IHS, 2013].
